Table 2 Catalysts Weak acid desorption amount (μmol/g) Media−strong desorption amount (μmol/g) Strong desorption amount (μmol/g) Total desorption amount (μmol/g) CuV/Ti 32.7 67.2 38.5 138.4 Ca−CuV/Ti 34.0 18.2 13.6 65.8 V/Ti 19.1 25.9 51.9 96.9 Ca−V/Ti 39.0 46.8 0.0 85.8 Revealing the Ca resistance enhancement mechanism for the NH3−SCR reaction over VTi catalyst by CuO modification Yang Zheng Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft a c Yangyang Guo Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ Wenpo Shan Validation Data curation Writing – review & editing b Zhihua Lian Writing – review & editing b Tingyu Zhu Supervision Project administration a b ⁎⁎ a CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, P. China. b Center for Excellence in Regional Atmospheric Environment, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xiamen 361021, China Center for Excellence in Regional Atmospheric Environment, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences Xiamen 361021 China Center for Excellence in Regional Atmospheric Environment, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xiamen 361021, China. c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China. ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China. CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Innovation Academy for Green Manufacture, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Currently, NO x emission control by the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3−SCR) technology for the cement industry has become urgent in China. The poisoning effect of Ca species from cement flue gas on V2O5/TiO2(V/Ti) catalysts still faces severe challenges. For the first time, CuO was investigated for the possibility of Ca resistance enhancement on V/Ti catalysts. The activity tests show that the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst maintains a good performance with an NO conversion above 80% between 260 − 330 °C, while the highest NO conversion of Ca−V/Ti in the test temperature range is only 52.4%. According to the characterization results, CaO is easier to adsorb on CuO than V2O5, thus retaining the V active sites. Due to the cycles of 2Cu2+ + V3+ ↔ 2Cu+ + V5+, CuO modification can significantly improve the redox ability of the V/Ti catalyst. In situ DRIFTS results show that the effect of CaO poisoning on the adsorption rate and reactivity of NH x over Ca−CuV/Ti is less than that of Ca−V/Ti. CaO even promotes the formation of the active nitrate species over CuV/Ti, which is the main reason for its strong Ca resistance. This study provides theoretical support for the industrial application of anti−Ca poisoning SCR catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) Alkali poisoning Anti−Ca ability CuO modification V/Ti catalyst 1 Introduction NO x from the combustion of fossil fuels poses serious environmental problems. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3 −SCR) has efficient and stable denitration performance and is one of the Best Available Control Technology (BACT) at present [1–3]. NH3 −SCR has been widely applied with ultralow NO x emission standards of below 50 mg/Nm3 in China [4]. With the completion of ultralow emission reformation in the thermal power industry, NO x emission control in the cement industry has become urgent in China. Different from the flue gas in the thermal power industry, the calcium−based compound concentration in particle materials for cement kilns can reach as high as 1 kg/Nm3 [5], and the calcium content in particles can reach over 60%. Therefore, it is almost unavoidable for the commercial V2O5 −TiO2 (VTi) catalyst [6–8] to be poisoned by calcium−based compounds from ash in the flue gas. As in our previous work [9–11], the NO conversion for VWTi and VTi catalysts declined by 72% and 35% at 300 °C after CaO poisoning, respectively. Most SCR catalysts in the cement industry were designed for no more than two years, which greatly inhibited their further application. Hence, a novel catalyst with high NO removal efficiency and good calcium resistance is urgently needed [12,13]. The serious destruction of V5+ reducibility and the substantial reduction of surface V species acidity are two major reasons for VTi catalyst deactivation. Nicosia et al. [14] found that Ca2+ occupied the nonatomic hole sites of the V2O5 (010) surface, which results in blockage of surface acids and V5+=O sites. More importantly, studies found that the CaO species located on the VTi catalyst have high activity in the catalytic conversion of NH3 to NO [9]. Thus, to improve the anti−calcium ability of VTi catalysts, protecting V species from poisonous CaO is an effective strategy that can maintain reducibility and/or surface acidity. CuO is a typical p − type semiconductor metal oxide. Its high Cu−O binding activity plays an important role in various redox catalytic reactions [15]. Comprehensive studies on CuO−V2O5 show that the formation of Cu−O−V species renders the aggregation of dispersed vanadium oxide [16], and the aggregated vanadium species are more conducive to NH3 adsorption [7] and easier to reduce [16]. Yu et al. [17] found that vanadium species interacted with TiO2 by copper species, and they ascribed the better NH3 −SCR performance to the generation of more V4+. The existence of the redox cycle of V4+ + Cu2+ ↔ V5+ + Cu+ was also reported by Chen et al. [18] for enhanced activity. Gao [19] and Cui [20] showed that unlike the alkali metals K and Na, the alkaline earth metal Ca seems to have a strong interaction with Cu, resulting in substantially more Cu2+ and Cu+ ions reduced to Cu0. Therefore, CuO may be a decent additive for VTi catalysts to optimize their tolerance to calcium species. Few studies have focused on using CuO to improve the alkali resistance of NH3 −SCR catalysts. Kang et al. [21] found that CuO modification effectively enhanced the anti−K poisoning ability of CeTiO x catalysts due to the substantial oxygen storage capacity and redox property of Ce and the synergistic effects. Wang et al. [22] studied the promotion effect of copper doping on the potassium resistance of V/Ti catalyst. It was found that the good NH3 adsorption capacity and redox ability, the increase in reduced vanadium species, and active oxygen species are the main factors affecting good CuV/TiO2 performance. The topic of VTi anti−Ca ability by CuO modification has hardly been reported, but the interaction between CuO−V2O5 and its effect on anti−calcium performance is of interest, which is essential to prolong the service life of SCR catalysts in the cement industry. Accordingly, 1% CuO was loaded by the impregnation method on the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst in this study. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized and the in situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was used to explore the poisoning resistance mechanism. 1.1 Experimental section The V/Ti and CuV/Ti catalysts with 3 wt% V2O5 and 1 wt% CuO (when used) loaded on commercial titania P25 were prepared by the impregnation method, as reported previously (Zheng et al. [9,11]). More experimental details can be found in the Support Information (SI), which also provides experimental details about the SCR measurements and catalytic characterizations. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalytic activity and H2O + SO2 tolerance As shown in Fig. 1(a), the CuV/Ti catalyst yields almost 100% NO conversion and above 90% N2 selectivity within 220 − 320 °C. The V/Ti catalyst also shows high SCR efficiency and N2 selectivity at 225 − 350 °C. After CaO poisoning, the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst still maintains more than 80% NO conversion within 260 − 330 °C. However, the NO conversion of Ca−V/Ti decreases to less than 50%, and the N2 selectivity is also markedly reduced. Flue gases from stationary sources usually contain gas impurities such as water and sulfur dioxide. To investigate the industrial application performance, the SO2 and/or H2O resistance performance of V/Ti and CuV/Ti catalysts was measured at 275 °C. The evaluation results of the SCR reaction under a 5% water content are shown in Fig. 1(c). Although the temperature window of CuV/Ti moves to a high temperature, it can still achieve nearly 100% NO conversion, which is much higher than that of V/Ti. Fig. 1(d) shows that when H2O was added to the catalytic reaction system, the NO conversion of V/Ti and CuV/Ti immediately decreased by 7.5% and 7.0%, respectively. When SO2 was added, the NO conversion of V/Ti and CuV/Ti declined slowly over time. The feeding of H2O and SO2 was stopped after 18 h of reaction, it can be seen that the NO conversion of V/Ti and CuV/Ti recovers to 90.4% and 96.5%, respectively. The conversions that do not reach the beginning level may be due to the sulfation of active species or the ammonium sulfates (bisulfates) covering the active species[23]. In summary, Fig. 1 indicates that CuV/Ti has good alkali-resistance, water resistance, and sulfur resistance, and is a promising catalyst for industrial applications. The long−term stability of CuV/Ti is also tested to ensure that the morphology of the catalyst is stably operated (Fig. S1), and the NO conversion of the CuV/Ti catalyst is reduced by 6% at 275 °C for 48 h. The conclusion could be that CuV/Ti has perfect stability under the testing conditions. 2.2 Bulk structure analysis The XRD patterns in Fig. 2 reveal that all catalysts have only characteristic diffraction peaks of TiO2, indicating that the active components are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the support without agglomeration[24]. CaO does not affect the crystal structure of the catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. S2 that the catalysts have similar pore structures. Table 1 shows that the specific surface area, pore size, and total pore volume of the CuV/Ti catalyst remain unchanged after CaO poisoning; while the VTi catalyst decreases by nearly 50% compared to those of the V/Ti catalyst. This may be one of the reasons for the significant decrease in the activity of Ca−V/Ti catalysts[25]. The Raman spectroscopy is used to study the structures of surface species dispersed on the titania surface. Fig. 3(a) shows that the Raman feature of anatase structure is predominated in all the investigated samples. Three major peaks at 396 cm−1, 516 cm−1, and 639 cm−1 are observed and assigned to four fundamental active modes Eg, A1 g/B1 g, and B1 g, where A1 g and B1 g bands are superimposed at 516 cm−1 [26]. The strong Raman bands of anatase at low shift ranges limit the interpretation of information for surface structures. Thus, a partially enlarged view of 750–1050 cm−1 is presented in Fig. 3(b). The weak second-order feature of anatase at 796 cm−1 is assigned to the first overtone of B1 g bands at 396 cm−1. For the Ca–V/Ti sample, the band appears at 987 cm−1 corresponding to the characteristic vibration of V = O in isolated VO x species[27], as shown in Fig. 3(b). The 987 cm−1 band disappears after Cu or Ca species introduce. The peak shift mainly resulted from the structural transformation of vanadium species, which suggests that an interaction between vanadium oxide and copper or calcium oxide occurs. For the samples of Ca–V/Ti, CuV/Ti, and Ca–CuV/Ti, the band at ca. 920 cm−1 can be observed. This band corresponds to the vibrations of the V-O-V bond in two-dimension vanadium oxide patches[16]. A redshift of the 920 cm−1 bands following CaO loadings is observed for CuV/Ti, and the vibrations of the V-O-V bond are different between Ca-CuV/Ti and Ca-V/Ti, this phenomenon illustrated that CuO affected the interaction between Ca and V. These spectral changes indicate that the presence of copper oxide alters the states of dispersed vanadium oxide, i.e., the interaction between copper oxide and preloaded vanadium oxide species takes place and V-O-Cu bands have been formed. 2.3 Surface acidity and XPS analysis The results of NH3 −temperature programmed desorption spectra (NH3 −TPD) are shown in Fig. 4(a) and Table 2. The NH3 desorption amount is 1.43 times higher when doping Cu species compared with V/Ti. The NH3 desorption amount of CuV/Ti decreased by 52.5% after CaO poisoning and retained a considerable number of strong adsorption sites. The total desorption amount of V/Ti was reduced by only 11.5% after CaO poisoning. However, the strong desorption sites on Ca−V/Ti almost all disappeared. The results demonstrate that CaO poisoning severely harms the surface acidity of V/Ti and CuV/Ti catalysts. The XPS characterization results of Cu 2p are shown in Fig. 4(b), and it can be seen that CaO poisoning has a great impact on Cu active sites. The proportion of Cu+/CuTotal increases greatly from 57.02% to 73.72%, and the binding energy of Cu decreases by 0.62 eV, indicating that the electron cloud density of Cu increases due to the addition of CaO. In contrast, the XPS results of O 1 s, Ca 2p, and V 2p, as shown in Fig. S3–S4. It can be seen from Fig. S4(a) that the binding energy of Ca in Ca-VTi and Ca-CuV/Ti catalysts shows a deviation of about 0.4–0.5 eV, indicating that Ca is in a different electronic environment on the two catalysts. It indicates that Ca has a large effect on the electronic environment of Cu, considering the measurement error. Fig. S4(b) shows that the electron binding energy of V shifted toward the high binding energy for both V after loading CaO (Ca-VTi) or CuO (CuV/Ti) on the V/Ti catalyst, indicating that CaO and CuO combined with V2O5 to affect the electronic environment of V. While the peak position of V on the Ca-CuV/Ti sample is consistent with V/Ti, combined with the test results of Cu 2p in Fig. 4(b), it can be speculated that CaO mainly binds to CuO. The Raman and XRD results show no significant changes in the crystal structure of TiO2 before and after loading the components of V, Cu, and Ca. And it can be seen from Fig. S4(c) that the Ti 2p of XPS in CuV/Ti catalyst is consistent with that in V/Ti catalysts, indicating the electronic environment of TiO2 remain unchanged. In summary, it is speculated that CuO has no significant effect on TiO2. To further explain the effect of CaO poisoning on the strong acid sites, DFT calculations were carried out, as shown in Fig. 5. The calculation results show that the adsorption energy between CaO and V2O5(010) is − 3.51 eV and that between CaO and CuO(111) is − 4.05 eV; thus, it can be concluded that CaO is easier to adsorb on CuO than V2O5. Therefore, CaO poisoning transforms a large number of VO into V−O−Ca in the absence of CuO, resulting in a significant reduction of Lewis strong acid sites provided by VO. When CuO is added to the catalyst, CaO preferentially binds to Cu and retains the VO bond, so Ca−CuV/Ti still possesses certain strong acid sites, as exhibited in Fig. 4(a). According to the literature[28], CaO binds to CuO in two ways: I. The active Cu-O bond allows Ca2+ to replace Cu2+ and form oxygen vacancies. CaO → Ca ′ ′ Cu + V O ̈ + O O x II. Entering the cell as an interstitial ion. 2 CaO → Ca ′ ′ Cu + O O x + Ca + + i According to the O 1 s results shown in Fig. S4(d), it is presumed that Ca2+ is mainly substituted for Cu2+ to form oxygen vacancies in the binding mode since the percentage of O β representing oxygen vacancies[29] in the Ca-CuV/Ti sample increased from 8.82% to 10.22%. Fig. 6 shows the mental dispersion and the turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the four catalysts. First, the addition of CuO increased the metal dispersion of the V/Ti catalyst by 3.47%. Second, the active metal dispersion of the V/Ti catalyst decreased by 0.93% due to CaO poisoning. In contrast, the metal dispersion of the CuV/Ti catalyst decreased by only 0.32% after CaO poisoning. It can be seen from the test results that CuO not only helps increase the surface dispersion of active metals but also enhances the anti−CaO poisoning ability. In terms of the TOFs, CuO addition increased the TOFs of the V/Ti catalyst by 5.7 times. Although the TOFs of CuV/Ti decreased significantly after CaO poisoning, it was still higher than VTi. 2.4 Reducibility analysis The results of the reducibility of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 7(a), for the V/Ti catalyst, a broad peak at about 414 °C belongs to the reduction of V5+ to V3+ [30]. The V5+ reduction peak on the Ca-VTi catalyst increased by 72 °C, indicating that CaO weakens the reducibility of V species. Peak fit 4.1 software was used to fit the H2-TPR test results of the CuV/Ti catalyst. Two reduction peaks can be seen on CuV/Ti catalyst. The peak at around 200 °C is attributed to Cu2+ → Cu+. The peak at 240 °C is attributed to Cu+ → Cu0. The reduction peaks of V species may overlap with Cu[31,32]. The test results firstly indicated that the CuO modification could significantly enhance the reducing ability of the V/Ti catalyst. Secondly, the results also indicated that with CuO addition, the V/Ti catalyst turned from a single V active center to a double V+Cu active center, thus inferring 2Cu2+ + V3+ ↔ 2Cu+ + V5+ [33]. The reduction peaks of the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst remain the same as those of the CuV/Ti catalyst, indicating that the CuO modification can effectively protect the reducing ability of the V/Ti component. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the initial H2 consumption rate decreased in the following order: Ca-CuV/Ti > CuV/Ti > V/Ti ＞ Ca-V/Ti. CuO addition improved the low-temperature reducibility of catalysts obviously, which is beneficial for the catalytic reaction. In summary, CuO modification can effectively improve the tolerance of V/Ti catalysts to CaO species. 2.5 In situ DRIFTS study 2.5.1 Reaction of NO+O2 with preadsorbed NH3 It can be seen from the comparison between Fig. S5 and S6, fresh CuV/Ti possesses a good capacity for NH3 adsorption at 100 °C. While the NH3 adsorption strength of the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst is reduced by nearly half. In Fig. 8(a and a′), the peak at 1432 cm−1 on the CuV/Ti catalyst is assigned to the adsorbed NH4+ species, and the peaks at 1597 and 1241 cm−1 are assigned to the adsorbed NH3 species, which are generated with the smooth adsorption of NH3. After the introduction of NO+O2, these ammonia species gradually disappeared within 10 min, indicating that the adsorbed ammonia have high reactivity. Finally, no obvious nitrate species appeared, indicating that the E-R mechanism mainly occurred on the CuV/Ti catalyst. For the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst in Fig. 8(b and b′), only the peaks at 1469 cm−1 ascribed to the NH4+ species appeared, and the adsorption peak intensity of the NH3 species is weak. This indicates that the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface are severely damaged after CaO poisoning. After adding NO+O2, the preadsorbed NH3 species disappeared within 5 min, proving the activity of adsorbed ammonia species. Different from CuV/Ti, more peaks of nitrogen oxide adsorption species appeared after the ammonia species were consumed, indicating that CaO promoted nitrogen oxide adsorption, which is consistent with the test results of NO+O2 −TPD (Fig. S10). When the catalysts are preadsorbed with NO+O2, as shown in Figs. S11 and S12, the adsorption capacity of NO x on Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst is much higher than that on CuV/Ti catalyst, which is consistent with the results in Fig. 8(b and b′). For the CuV/Ti catalyst (Fig. 8c, c′), almost no nitrate species emerge due to the adsorption of NO+O2. While for the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst (Fig. 8d, d′), monodentate nitrate (1323 cm−1 and 1482 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1522 cm−1), and bridging nitrate (1548 cm−1) species are observed. After the introduction of NH3, the nitrate species gradually disappeared. Meanwhile, ammonium species appear over the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst, which is much fewer than those of the CuV/Ti catalyst. These results inferred that alkali earth metal poisoning promotes the formation of nitrate species and the increased NO x adsorption ability brings higher NO reduction efficiency due to the Fast−SCR reaction pathway. From the above analysis, it can be inferred that the reaction between adsorbed ammonia species and gaseous NO on CuV/Ti catalyst mainly follows the Eley-Rideal mechanism; in addition to the above reaction mechanism, the reaction between adsorbed ammonia species and adsorbed nitrogen oxides is also increased on Ca-CuV/Ti catalyst, that is, Langmuir Hinshelwood mechanism. 2.5.2 Kinetic study During the in situ DRIFTs experiment, we found that the adsorption and reaction rate on the Ca−CuVTi catalyst seemed to be faster than those on the other catalysts. To prove this viewpoint, the NH3 adsorption data from Figs. S5− 8 are collected and are shown in Fig. 9 as a function of time. The NH3 reaction data with NO+O2 in Fig. 8(b) are based on Fig. 8(a), b and Fig. S9. The first derivative of the data is processed to obtain the change rate of peak intensity. Compared with the CuV/Ti catalyst, the Ca-CuV/Ti catalyst still maintains a good NH3 adsorption rate. The adsorption rate of NH3 on Ca-CuV/Ti and CuV/Ti catalysts is higher than that on Ca-VTi and VTi. In addition, the reaction rate of NO+O2 with NH3 on Ca−CuV/Ti is the fastest among the four catalysts, as shown in Fig. 9(b), which may be one of the reasons that Ca−CuV/Ti still has a good SCR reaction performance. 2.5.3 Relationship between structure and activity As shown in Fig. 10, it was identified that the CuO additive acted as a functional antipoisoning site and worked to improve the activity and resistance to CaO of V−based catalysts. The abundant acid sites of CuO and the additional redox cycle of 2Cu2+ + V4+ ↔ 2Cu+ + V5+ ensured the enhanced deNO x reaction. NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites are the main reaction sites. Combined with the catalytic reaction activity results, the catalyst is active above 200 °C, so the strength and amount of acid sites above 200 °C are especially important for the catalytic reaction. The CuO addition maintains the strong acid sites above 300 °C, which is beneficial for the catalytic reaction. Cu species showed strong binding ability with CaO. At the same time, CaO creates new alkaline sites and promotes the adsorption of active NO x . Therefore, the dual promotion of CuO enables CuV/Ti catalysts to effectively control NO x emission in the presence of alkaline earth metals. 3 Conclusions This work focuses on the anti−calcium ability of CuO−modified V/Ti catalysts. Activity tests show that the CuV/Ti catalyst yields close to 100% NO conversion and outstanding N2 selectivity within 220 − 330 °C. Cu doping significantly improved the anti−calcium poisoning performance, and the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst still maintained a good performance above 80% within 260 − 330 °C compared with Ca−V/Ti. CuV/Ti also has perfect water and sulfur resistance and stability under testing conditions. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized, and the crystal structures, surface area, and pore structure had no direct correlation with deNO x activity. The XPS and DFT calculation results show that CaO more easily adsorbs on CuO than V2O5, and the adsorption greatly increases the proportion of Cu+/CuTotal from 57.02% to 73.72%. TOF calculations further confirmed that CuO increases both the surface dispersion of active metals and the anti−CaO poisoning ability. Additionally, CuO modification can significantly enhance the reduction ability of the V/Ti catalyst for the additional redox cycles of 2Cu2+ + V3+ ↔ 2Cu+ + V5+. With the CuO addition, the V/Ti catalyst turned from a single V active center to a double V+Cu active center. In situ DRIFTS was used to explore the poisoning resistance mechanism. CaO poisoning has less impact on the adsorption rate and reactivity of NHx over Ca−CuV/Ti than Ca−V/Ti, which is the natural reason for the strong CaO resistance of CuV/Ti. On the other hand, alkali earth metal poisoning promotes the formation of nitrate species, which promotes the Langmuir−Hinshelwood mechanism pathway. This study provides theoretical support for the industrial application of anti−Ca poisoning SCR catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Currently, NO x emission control by the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3−SCR) technology for the cement industry has become urgent in China. The poisoning effect of Ca species from cement flue gas on V2O5/TiO2(V/Ti) catalysts still faces severe challenges. For the first time, CuO was investigated for the possibility of Ca resistance enhancement on V/Ti catalysts. The activity tests show that the Ca−CuV/Ti catalyst maintains a good performance with an NO conversion above 80% between 260 − 330 °C, while the highest NO conversion of Ca−V/Ti in the test temperature range is only 52.4%. According to the characterization results, CaO is easier to adsorb on CuO than V2O5, thus retaining the V active sites. Due to the cycles of 2Cu2+ + V3+ ↔ 2Cu+ + V5+, CuO modification can significantly improve the redox ability of the V/Ti catalyst. In situ DRIFTS results show that the effect of CaO poisoning on the adsorption rate and reactivity of NH x over Ca−CuV/Ti is less than that of Ca−V/Ti. CaO even promotes the formation of the active nitrate species over CuV/Ti, which is the main reason for its strong Ca resistance. This study provides theoretical support for the industrial application of anti−Ca poisoning SCR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Revealing the Ca resistance enhancement mechanism for the NH3−SCR reaction over VTi catalyst by CuO modification
